llm_response.description: The retinal fundus image shows multiple dark spots scattered throughout the retina, indicative of hemorrhages. There are also lighter spots that could represent exudates. The optic disc appears slightly blurred, and there is a presence of venous dilation. No clear signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots are visible.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without any venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina without signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no visible cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina with no evident signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc and macula. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The image does not show cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization. The overall appearance suggests a healthy retina without significant signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple dark spots in the central region, likely representing microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. Additionally, there are some lighter areas that could be cotton wool spots or exudates. The blood vessels appear slightly dilated, but there is no clear evidence of neovascularization. The optic disc is visible, and the macula appears to have some changes, possibly due to edema.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and the surrounding retinal area. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without any signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots or other abnormalities present.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The blood vessels appear normal without signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no cotton wool spots present. The overall appearance suggests no significant signs of diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright spots consistent with hard exudates, primarily located in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are also several dark red spots that could represent microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or significant venous changes. Cotton wool spots are not clearly visible in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows several signs indicative of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms visible as small red dots scattered throughout the retina. Hemorrhages are present, appearing as darker red spots. There are also hard exudates, which are yellowish-white lesions, indicating lipid deposits. Cotton wool spots, which are soft white patches, are visible, suggesting nerve fiber layer infarctions. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no evidence of neovascularization or significant venous beading.

The retinal fundus image shows the optic disc on the left with clear margins. There are visible blood vessels radiating from the optic disc. In the central area, there are several small yellowish-white spots, which are likely hard exudates. These are located near the macula. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization visible in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. The blood vessels appear normal with no signs of venous beading or neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. The retinal background is uniform without any cotton wool spots or other abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear view of the optic disc and macula. There are visible blood vessels with no significant signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or exudates. There are no cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization observed. The overall appearance suggests no significant diabetic retinopathy changes.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright yellow-white spots consistent with hard exudates, primarily located in the central and temporal regions. There are also several dark red spots indicative of microaneurysms and possible dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. No obvious signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots are visible. The optic disc appears normal, and the macula shows some involvement with exudates.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple bright yellowish spots, likely representing hard exudates, scattered in the central and mid-peripheral regions. There are also some darker areas that could indicate microaneurysms or small hemorrhages. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no obvious neovascularization or significant venous beading visible. Cotton wool spots are not clearly identifiable in this image.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also several hard exudates visible, particularly in the superior region. Cotton wool spots are present, indicating localized retinal ischemia. No signs of neovascularization are observed. The optic disc appears normal, and there is no significant venous beading.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple hard exudates arranged in a circinate pattern, which are bright yellow-white lesions. There are no obvious signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, venous beading, or neovascularization visible in this image.

Cotton wool spots are visible, indicating localized ischemia. There are also hard exudates present, particularly in the macular region, suggesting macular edema. Neovascularization is observed near the optic disc, indicating proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The presence of these features suggests significant retinal damage.

The retinal fundus image shows multiple hard exudates clustered in the macular region, indicating significant lipid leakage. There are also scattered microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages visible throughout the retina. No signs of neovascularization or cotton wool spots are observed. The presence of these features suggests moderate non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
